Consider the scenario where a complex function \\( z(t) \\) evolves in the complex plane under the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\) where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. We study how the Fourier Transform, defined by \\( \\mathcal{F}(z(t)) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), affects our understanding of the system.

If \\( z(t) \\) initially starts as \\( z_0 \\) and evolves according to \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\) without any interventions, will the Fourier Transform of \\( z(t) \\) at any time t reflect changes due solely to the natural evolution of \\( z \\) under its differential equation?
Explanation: The Fourier Transform of \\( z(t) \\), being a linear integral transform, directly captures how the frequency components of \\( z(t) \\) evolve. Since \\( z(t) = z_0 e^{i\\omega t} \\), the transformation captures this evolution without alteration, reflecting changes due to the differential equation alone.
